sequence.notes: Selective silylation of the primary alcohol of methyl (2R)-2,3-dihydroxypropanoate using TBDPSCl to form methyl (2R)-3-(tert-butyldiphenylsilyloxy)-2-hydroxypropanoate. The stereocenter at C2 is preserved.
Benzylation of a secondary alcohol using benzyl bromide and silver oxide.
Methyl ester is reduced to an aldehyde using DIBAL-H while retaining stereochemistry and protecting groups.

Ethynylmagnesium bromide adds to an aldehyde to form a secondary alcohol. Stereochemistry of the existing chiral center is preserved; new chiral center is formed without specified stereocontrol in the product image.
Alkyne dicobalt hexacarbonyl complex formation and subsequent cyclization (Nicholas reaction) forming a fused pyran-furan system.

substeps.notes: A Ferrier rearrangement of a dihydropyran with an enol ether and TMSOTf catalyst.
Hydrolysis of two acetate esters to hydroxyl groups using potassium carbonate in methanol.
Catalytic hydrogenation of the alkene in the dihydropyran ring to yield a tetrahydropyran. Stereochemistry is retained, and methyl ester and alcohol groups are unaffected.
Conversion of a primary alcohol to an alkyl iodide with retention of configuration.

sequence.notes: Oxidative decomplexation of a dicobalt hexacarbonyl alkyne complex to reveal a terminal alkyne. The reactant SMILES represents the organic scaffold with the alkyne; the Co2(CO)6 complex, visually depicted in the reactant, is omitted from the SMILES due to limitations in standard SMILES representation for such bridging organometallic complexes. The product SMILES is identical to the reactant's organic scaffold.
Oxidation of an iodomethyl group to an aldehyde.
Radical hydrostannylation of terminal alkyne and reduction of aldehyde to alcohol.
Dess Martin oxidation of a secondary alcohol to a ketone.
Stereoselective reduction of an α,β-unsaturated ketone to a secondary alcohol using K-Selectride.
Deprotection of TBDPS silyl ether to alcohol and protodestannylation of vinylstannane to an exocyclic alkene.
Oxidative cleavage of exocyclic alkene followed by reduction of the resulting ketone to a secondary alcohol.
Protection of a vicinal diol as an isopropylidene acetal.
Primary alcohol is oxidized to an aldehyde using Dess-Martin Periodinane.
Horner-Wadsworth-Emmons olefination of an aldehyde with a ketone-phosphonate to form an alpha,beta-unsaturated ketone.

substeps.notes: One hydroxyl group of 1,4-butanediol is selectively protected as a TBDPS silyl ether.
Primary alcohol oxidized to aldehyde. Reaction involves 2 steps for the yield calculation.
Addition of ethynylmagnesium bromide to an aldehyde, forming a secondary propargyl alcohol with a TBDPS protecting group.
Formation of a dicobalt hexacarbonyl alkyne complex from a terminal alkyne.
Nicholas reaction where a dicobalt hexacarbonyl complexed propargyl alcohol reacts with a hydroxyester, forming an ether linkage with inversion of stereochemistry at the attacking hydroxyl center.

The dicobalt hexacarbonyl alkyne complex in the reactant is represented as a simple alkyne ('C#C') in the SMILES, as standard SMILES cannot accurately depict the complex. The reaction involves deprotection of this complex and esterification of the carboxylic acid to a methyl ester. A one-carbon difference in the alkyl chain length connecting the TBDPS group to the alkyne-bearing carbon is observed between the reactant (4 methylenes) and product (3 methylenes) structures as depicted in the screenshot. SMILES for each structure accurately reflect their respective drawings.
Intramolecular radical cyclization of an alkyl bromide onto an alkyne, forming a tetrahydrofuran ring with an exocyclic double bond.
Deprotection of TBDPS silyl ether to a primary alcohol.
Oxidation of a primary alcohol to an aldehyde using Dess-Martin Periodinane.

substeps.reagents: CrCl2, CoPc, LiCl, Mn, proton sponge, ZrCp2Cl2
substeps.notes: Intramolecular cyclization of an aldehyde with a diiodoalkene catalyzed by chromium and a chiral auxiliary to form a new 6-membered ring and a secondary alcohol.
Protection of a secondary alcohol as a TBS ether using TBSOTf and 2,6-lutidine.
Methyl ester is converted to a beta-ketophosphonate via reaction with a phosphonate carbanion.

sequence.notes: Deprotection of TBS ether and 1,3-dioxane ketal, along with reduction of an alpha,beta-unsaturated ketone to a saturated ketone.

sequence.reaction_type: Oxidative Deprotection (Benzyl Ether) / Intramolecular Ketal/Acetal Formation
sequence.notes: Oxidative deprotection of a benzyl ether using DDQ, followed by intramolecular cyclization involving a ketone to form a complex pentacyclic ketal/acetal system.
Mesylation of a secondary alcohol.

Nozaki-Hiyama-Kishi reaction for the reductive coupling of an iodo-alkene with an aldehyde, forming a new C-C bond and reducing the alkene to an alkane, while the aldehyde is reduced to a secondary alcohol. The mesylate group remains unchanged. The 5-membered lactone in the reactant and product structures is encoded as a 5-membered ether ring in the provided SMILES, which is a structural mismatch with the image; this issue was noted but not corrected to avoid full molecule re-parsing.

substeps.notes: Stereoselective allylation of a dihydropyran derivative.
Terminal alkene is cleaved and oxidized to a carboxylic acid using OsO4 and oxone.
Intramolecular bromolactonization of an unsaturated pyranose derivative, forming a fused bicyclic lactone.
Reductive dehalogenation (Br to H) and deprotection of acetate esters (OAc to OH) of a bicyclic lactone structure.
The primary hydroxyl group is selectively converted to an iodide group using iodine, triphenylphosphine, and imidazole.

A Nicholas reaction where a dicobalt hexacarbonyl alkyne complexed alcohol reacts with the hydroxyl group of the lactone, forming an ether linkage. Stereochemistry at the alcohol-bearing carbon of the reagent is inverted.
Oxidative decomplexation of a dicobalt hexacarbonyl alkyne complex using cerium ammonium nitrate to yield a free terminal alkyne.
Reduction of lactone to hemiacetal using DIBAL-H.
The anomeric hydroxyl group (hemiacetal) is converted to a methyl acetal (methoxy group) via acid-catalyzed reaction with methanol.
Dehydroiodination to form an exocyclic alkene.
Radical hydrostannylation of alkyne followed by cyclization and rearrangement of an exocyclic double bond to an endocyclic position.
Oxidation of a vinyl stannane to a ketone via cleavage of the alkene.
Alpha-alkylation of the lactone with methyl iodide via an enolate formed by LiHMDS.
Ketone is selectively reduced to a secondary alcohol. The newly formed alcohol has beta stereochemistry.
Oxidation of a primary alcohol to an aldehyde.

sequence.notes: Hydrolysis of methyl ester to carboxylic acid, desulfonylation of mesylate, and subsequent intramolecular cyclization to form a new furan ring and a new tetrahydropyran ring with an exocyclic double bond. Atom count analysis of the generated SMILES shows Reactant: C61 H102 O16 S1, Product: C60 H98 O14. This indicates a loss of 1 carbon. Based on the functional group changes (loss of methyl from methyl ester and loss of methyl from mesylate), a net loss of 2 carbons is expected. This discrepancy might arise from the complexity of the structure and automated SMILES generation/interpretation or a subtle rearrangement not immediately obvious.
Intramolecular esterification to form a macrolactone from a seco-acid using Shiina's reagent (2-methyl-6-nitrobenzoic anhydride) and base.
Acid-catalyzed hydrolysis of the methyl hemiacetal (methoxy group) to a hydroxyl group.

The terminal hydroxyl group of the reactant undergoes a cascade reaction with the diazo phosphonate, forming a new 5-membered cyclic ether with an adjacent phosphonate and hydroxyl group, and consuming one of the exocyclic methylene groups.
Horner-Wadsworth-Emmons olefination between an aldehyde equivalent on the macrocyclic reactant and the alpha-ketophosphonate reagent to form an E-configured alpha,beta-unsaturated ketone (enone).

substeps.notes: Reduction of the enediol double bond in L-ascorbic acid to yield dihydro-L-ascorbic acid.

The starting lactone with multiple hydroxyl groups undergoes bromination at two positions and acetylation of the remaining hydroxyls. Two hydroxyls are replaced by bromine atoms (at C2 and C3), and the remaining two hydroxyls (at C5 of the side chain and C4 of the lactone ring) are acetylated. All stereocenters are retained but adjusted based on new substituents.
HBr elimination to form an alpha,beta-unsaturated lactone.
Acid-catalyzed hydrolysis of an acetate ester to a hydroxyl group.
Hydrogenation of an α,β-unsaturated lactone, saturating the double bond while preserving existing stereocenters.

substeps.reagents: BF3 • Et2O, Dicobalt hexacarbonyl alkyne complex
substeps.notes: Nicholas reaction (alcohol substitution) involving a dicobalt hexacarbonyl alkyne complex. Stereochemistry for all chiral centers has been corrected to match the drawing. The dicobalt hexacarbonyl complex has been represented in SMILES using a bridging cluster notation for the Co atoms and carbonyl ligands.

Deprotection of a dicobalt hexacarbonyl alkyne complex to yield the free alkyne. The reactant SMILES represents the organic alkyne backbone, as standard SMILES cannot accurately depict the organometallic complex shown in the image.
Intramolecular radical cyclization of a bromoalkyne to form a bicyclic furan-lactone system. Bromine is removed, and the alkyne is converted to an exocyclic alkene.
Alpha-hydroxylation of a lactone enolate.
TBDPS silyl ether deprotection to a primary alcohol.
Protection of the primary alcohol as a p-methoxybenzyl (PMB) ether using PMB-TCAI and CSA.
Ozonolysis of exocyclic alkene to a ketone.

Reduction of a dicarbonyl (lactone and ketone) system to form a polyol. The lactone ring is opened, and the ketone is reduced to a secondary alcohol. Stereochemistry of three existing chiral centers is retained; new chiral centers are formed at the ketone position and the former spiro carbon, with defined stereochemistry.
Protection of four hydroxyl groups with TBS (tert-butyldimethylsilyl) ethers. The PMB (p-methoxybenzyl) ether remains untouched.
PMB ether deprotection using DDQ.
Primary alcohol oxidized to aldehyde. Overall yield for 3 steps is 76%.
Horner-Wadsworth-Emmons olefination of an aldehyde with a phosphonate to form an alpha,beta-unsaturated ketone.
Methyl group added to the enone via conjugate addition. The carbon alpha to the furan (bearing the OTBS) inverts configuration, and a new stereocenter is created for the added methyl group.
Selective debenzylation of the primary benzyl ether to a primary alcohol using Raney Ni and H2. The PMB ether remains intact.
Oxidation of a primary alcohol to an aldehyde.

sequence.notes: Deprotection of three TBS (tert-butyldimethylsilyl) ethers to form three hydroxyl groups. The PMB (p-methoxybenzyl) ether remains intact.
DDQ-mediated deprotection of a PMB ether, yielding Halichondrin B.
